Of the couple's 5 children, 3 are students and the remaining two are still infants.  This loan will be used for Mr. Cheng to buy a new trailer.  In the future, he would like to help his wife expand her recycling business and also to send his children to university.

loans.use: To purchase a new trailer

loans.name: Mustafa

texts.en:
Mustafa S. is 56-year-old farmer, who lives with his family in Bilasuvar. Bilasuvar situated in the southern part of Azerbaijan. Mustafa is internally dislocated person from Nagorniy Karabakh who fled to Bilasuvar in 1993, during Azerbaijani-Armenian conflict. 

Mustafa started his small business in 1997. For money he saved he purchases his first calf and very soon this calf breeder to milkier cow. His income comes from selling milk and yoghurt. These products are in high demand in Azerbaijan, and Mustafa expand his business purchasing one additional milkier cow. There are two main products in demand: meat and dairies. Mustafa decided to try himself in selling meat production. For this purpose he applied for 1200 USD to purchase 3 calves to start selling meat production. Estimated cost for calf is 200-300.

loans.use: Going to purchase four calves for meat production

loans.name: Sara David

texts.pt:
Sara is a single mother living with her 3 children. She was a member of a solidarity group that organized to obtain a group loan. At that time, she received $25. She started the FDM loan program in 2000. Since then, her business has developed and she has introduced new products such as almonds and beans. She sells these products in bulk and she buys them in another province -- not the province where she lives and runs her business. With her profits she has been able to improve her house. Her children have a balanced diet. She wants to continue investing in her business to grow her profits and guarantee the schooling of her children.

Translated by Bianca Vargas, Kiva Volunteer.

Sara e solteira mas tem 3 filhos.Ela vive apenas com os seus filhos.Sara era membro de um grupo solidario que seorganizou para tomar dinheiro emprestado. O valor que ela recebeu na altura foi de $25. Ela entrou para o Programa de credito do Fundo de desenvolvimento em 2000. de la para ca o negocio dela foi desenvolvendo de tal modo que ela introduziu outros produtos para a venda tais como amendoim feijao. Ela vende estes produtos a grosso e compra-os numa outra Provincia diferente daquela onde ela vive e faz o seu negocio. Ela conseguiu com os rendimentos melhorar a sua casa. Os seus filhos estudam e tem uma dieta equlibrada. Ela quer continuar a investir no negoci dela para poder obter nais rendimentos para poder garantir os estudos dos seus filhos.

loans.use: For the purchase and transport of sacks of corn.

loans.name: Oyinye

texts.en:
Oyinye I. is 48 years old and married with 3 children. The family lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria.

Oyinye has a store where she sells foodstuffs. She is asking for a loan of $400 to enable her buy more foodstuffs to sell. She has been with LAPO for 5 years and she is faithful and dedicated. She has been in her business since 1983.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs for sale

loans.name: Pauline's Group

texts.en:
Pauline L. currently has 300 birds and collects 4 trays of eggs per day. She wants to buy more chicks and poultry feed. She also wants to cement her house’s floor.

Background on BRAC and BRAC Uganda

BRAC (Building Resources Across Communities) is a development organization that began operations in Bangladesh as a small-scale relief and rehabilitation project in 1972 to help the country overcome the devastation and trauma of the liberation war and focused on resettling refugees returning from India. Today, BRAC has emerged as an independent, virtually self-financed paradigm in sustainable human development. It is one of the largest Southern development organizations employing over 100,000 people, 61% of which are women, and working with the twin objectives of poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor. Diagnosing poverty in human terms and recognizing its multifaceted nature, BRAC approaches poverty alleviation with a holistic approach.

The successes of BRAC in the international development arena have stimulated a series of discussions, both with African delegations, who have visited BRAC programs, and with donors who work in Asia and Africa. Both the African countries and the donors have encouraged BRAC to join the development campaign in Africa to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and more recently to join the campaign of “ending poverty”, which is an area where Africa represents the greatest global challenge.

In Uganda, BRAC registered as a Non Government Organization (NGO) in January 2006 to undertake programs in Education, Health, Water & Sanitation, Agriculture & Livestock and Microfinance. The Microfinance and Education are the pioneer programs launched in Uganda and, as of July 2007, had served 21,273 borrowers and enrolled 1,155 adolescents in its education program.

loans.use: To increase egg production

loans.name: Dosseh

texts.fr:
Born in 1963, Mr A. Dosseh is married and a father of seven (7) children. Being an excellent poultry breeder in his area, he works with the best poultry saleswomen in his region. However, since he does not have a barn, the poultry is left free for robbers to take each night. To put an end to this problem, he would like to build a barn and buy more poultry, but lacks the financial means. He thus asks for a contribution of $500 which will help him make this project a reality. He would thus be able to meet his customers' needs, have a very good income and improve the living conditions of his family.

Translated from French by Ivana Kostic, Kiva Translator

Né en 1963, Monsieur A. Dosseh est marié et père de sept (7) enfants. Excellent éleveur de volailles de son milieu, il est sollicité par les bonnes femmes commerçantes de volailles de sa localité. Mais faute d’enclos, ses volailles sont laissées à la merci des voleurs chaque nuit. Pour mettre fin à ce problème, il décide de construire un enclos et s’acheter d’autres volailles mais faute de moyens financiers, il sollicite cet apport de $500 qui va lui servir à la réalisation de ce projet. Ainsi, il pourra satisfaire sa clientèle et avoir un très bon revenu afin d’améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.

loans.use: Construction of barn and purchase of poultry

loans.name: Alvin Alis

texts.es:
Alvin is a producer of basic grains, and cultivates rice and beans in the municipality of Concha, a department of Masaya, which is a productive high altitude town that draws on its favorable agro climatic conditions in order to harvest basic grains. Alvin has been doing this work for the past 15 years together with his family. His wife helps with the housework, while their 5 children work together with their father in the field harvesting the rice and bean seeds in order to obtain the right harvest and in this way be able to commercialize it. Since these are basic nutritious products in the Nicaraguan diet, there is a high demand for them.

At this time, Alvin needs to buy fertilizer for all of his crop since there is a constant risk throughout their production process.

Translated from Spanish by Katrina H, Kiva volunteer.

loans.use: Purchase Green Fertilizer for Rice Fields

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi H., 55 years old, joined TYM since 1999.  Her first two childrens are both grown up and have their own family, she lived with her husband and the youngest child at Phuc Yen of Vinh Phuc Province.  As the head of the women union in the village, she was the pioneer when it come to TYM and micro-credit.  Due to the suitable repayment period, everyone has been able to make use of their loans and increased their family's incomes.  A very active member of the community and a very trustworthy person, she has been voted in as the head of the women union for many years.  She has been using her loan to buy and resell medicines.  During this cycle, she would like to ask for another 1200 USD to buy additional medicines.  Her family monthly income has been around 200-220 USD.

Translated from Vietnamese by Anh H. Nguyen, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị Hạnh, 55 tuổi, tham gia vào Quỹ năm 1999. 2 người con lớn đã trưởng thành, chị sống cùng chồng và người con út tại Phúc Yên, Vĩnh Phúc. Là chi hội trưởng hội phụ nữ, sớm nhận thấy lợi ích khi tham gia vào Quỹ nên ngay từ những ngày đầu chị đã mạnh dạn tham gia và vận động nhiều chị em khác. Cơ chế hoàn trả tuần phù hợp với chị em khiến kinh tế của những thành viên tham gia được nâng lên trông thấy. Chị được mọi người tin tưởng và nhiều năm liền được bầu làm cụm trưởng. Ngoài ra chị Hạnh cũng là một trong những thành viên mạnh dạn vay vốn lớn đầu tư có hiệu quả nên việc hoàn trả rất đảm bảo. Số tiền vay từ Quỹ được chị Hạnh đầu tư cho việc buôn bán thuốc tân dược. Công việc bên Hội phụ nữ bận rộn, lại thêm phục vụ sức khoẻ cho bà con trong thôn nhưng chị vẫn luôn tham gia tích cực vào các hoạt động của cụm và chi nhánh. Vòng vốn này chị Hạnh tiếp tục vay 1200USD để mua thêm thuốc bán. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình chị là 200-220USD/tháng.

loans.use: Buy medicines

loans.name: Kidawa

texts.en:
Kidawa is a 32-year-old married woman. She is the mother of 2 small children, ages 8 and 12 years old. Kidawa owns a small salon. She also sells timber, a business which she began in 2000. She works every day from 6 a.m. to 8 p.m. and earns a monthly profit of about $300 from her sales.

In the past, Kidawa has taken out 2 successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more timber for her business.

loans.use: To buy more timber for her business.

loans.name: Pa

texts.en:
Pa L. is 39 years old and has resided in Kampong Cham province over ten years. She has a small business selling fishes and a variety of vegetables in a busy market to earn approximately $1.50 of profit each day. She started doing this business in 2000. Her husband is a construction worker ,building houses in the village, but sometimes he needs to go out of his village to do the construction, wherever he was hired. On average, he makes $5 of profit a day. This couple has four children, one of whom works collecting rubber in the village and resells it to the brokers. Normally the child makes around one dollar each day.

This couple would like to request a loan from Kiva to purchase wood to repair the leaking roof. This will provide the family with a stable house in the future.

loans.use: To purchase wood to repair the leaking roof.

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.es:
Mercedes is a hard-working person who, together with her husband, has been able to help the family business prosper. They have been working in this business for more than 20 years. They still have 2 children at home and live in the north part of the city.

This is the fifth loan she has requested, and she has an excellent credit record.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Mercedes es una persona muy trabajadora que junto a su marido sacaron adelante un negocio familiar trabajando en el mismo hace mas D. 20 años teniendo todavia a su cargo 2 hijos, ellos viven en la zona norte D. la ciudad.

Actualmente es el quinto credito que solicita D. forma individual, teniendo un excelente historial crediticio.

loans.use: Buy materials for making hats.

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita is a 26 year old wife and mother. She has one child who is in school.

Anita has been a food vendor for three years. She prepares and sells banku (a local dish prepared from milled maize and eaten with all kinds of local soups). Banku is a delicacy most Ghanaians eat everyday as breakfast, lunch or dinner. Anita also sells fried rice. Her business is doing well and she wants to expand her operations to serve more customers. She therefore wants to use this loan to buy more maize grains, vegetables, rice and assorted meat for her operation. She hopes this loan will help her increase her savings and thereby improve her family's well-being.

Anita is a member of the group called “Enka ho daa” (It shall come to pass). In this group, members agree to act as social collateral to guarantee access to loans and to help repay the loans for one another.

loans.use: To buy bags of dried maize grains, rice, vegetables, assorted meat and other groceries

loans.name: Mougnoun (La Patience). Group

texts.fr:
Mougnoun est un regroupement de six femmes  toutes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 34 ans et 3 enfants. Elles vivent dans des foyers monogames  dans un des  villages environnants  de la ville de Sikasso Kamalen Sirakoro (Préfecture de Sikasso troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Unies par des relations de travail et d’amitié ces femmes du groupe Mougnoun exercent le commerce de chaussures en plastique et des condiments alimentaires (concentée de tomate poissons fumés ou séchés etc).
Ce groupe de femme est à sa première expérience avec Soro Yiriwaso.
Elles comptent acheter avec ce prêt, au grand marché de Sikasso 35 paires de chaussures en plastique, 100kg de poissons fumés et séchés, 10 boites de concentrée de tomate et une grande quantité de condiments. Les produits ainsi achetés seront vendus  dans la ville de Sikasso en ambulant, au marché du quartier de Médine, dans le village de Kamalen Sirakoro et dans les foires des villages environnants pour la plupart en détail et au comptant à une clientèle essentiellement féminine. 
Elles envisagent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 15.000FCFAqui sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt et subvenir aux charges de la famille.
texts.en:
Mougnoun is a group of six married women who, on average, are 34 years old and have 3 children. They live in monogamous households in one of the villages surrounding the city of Sikasso, Kamalen Sirakoro (prefecture of Sikasso, third administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Linked by friendship and professional bonds, the women in the Mougnoun group sell plastic shoes, food products and condiments (tomato concentrate, smoked or dried fish, etc). This women group is seeking its first loan with Soro Yiriwaso, with which they intend to buy in the grand market of Sikasso, 35 pairs of plastic shoes, 100 kg of smoked and dried fish, 10 cans of tomato concentrate and a large amount of condiments. These products will then be sold itinerantly in Sikasso, in the market of the Médine quarter, in the village of Kamalen Sirakoro, and in the fairs of the surrounding villages. Most will be sold retail and for cash to a mainly female clientele. They foresee an average monthly profit of 15000 XOF that will serve to repay the loan and provide for family expenses.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy food products and plastic shoes

loans.name: Tith

texts.en:
Mr. Tith P. was born in 1986, and he now lives in Roneam Tnort Village in Takeo Province. 

He is single, and he is a farmer and duck breeder. Since his second business is going well, he wants to buy more ducks to raise, so he decided to ask for a loan to buy more ducks for breeding. He hopes to improve his living conditions with this loan.

loans.use: To buy more ducks for breeding.

loans.name: Doris

texts.es:
La señora Doris, socia del Grupo de Crédito Mientras Tanto “San Marcelo”, vive en la región y provincia de San Martín, distrito de Tarapoto. Se dedica a la venta de frutas y leña. Desarrolla la actividad en su domicilio ubicado en el Jr. San Marcelo  Mz H – Lt 07, lugar donde atiende a sus clientes con la amabilidad que la caracteriza. Decide iniciarse en el negocio para generar sus ingresos y estar en contacto tanto con sus amigos y como con otras personas. 

Con este préstamo de S/.800, el cual será cancelado en 6 meses, comprará frutas como plátanos de seda en racimos, naranjas, madarinas en sacos, piñas, paltas, entre otras frutas, además comprará leña en tercios para luego venderlos al menudeo.  

La señora Doris tiene 36 años de edad, vive con su esposo y sus 03 hijos quienes son la razón de su lucha constante para poder sacarlos adelante, además cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo y poco a poco está creciendo en su negocio. Espera arreglar su casa para implementarse con abarrotes.
texts.en:
Doris is a member of the San Marcelo Grupo de Credito Mientras Tanto and lives in the region and province of San Martín, in the distract of Tarapoto. She sells fruits and firewood. She started this business from her home, where she attends to her clients with her characteristic kindness. She decided to start the business to earn income and to be in contact with her friends and other people. With this loan of $275, which she will repay in six months, she will buy fruits, including bunches of bananas, oranges, mandarins, pineapples, avocados and other fruits. She will also buy firewood in thirds to later sell them retail. Doris is 36 years old and lives with her husband and her three children. They are the reason she struggles constantly to get the family ahead. She also counts on the support of her husband and little by little she is growing her business. She hopes to fix her house in order to sell groceries.

Translated from Spanish by Amani Roland, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fruits (bananas, oranges, mandarins).

loans.name: Victorine

texts.fr: Victorine K. est une revendeuse de poissons au grand marché d’Atakpamé, une ville située à environ 170 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. Passionnée par son activité et voulant la promouvoir, Victorine espère avec ce crédit augmenter ses achats en cherchant d’autres fournisseurs afin de réduire les prix d’achat et par conséquent une augmentation des marges bénéficiaires.
texts.en:
Victorine K. sells fish in the main market of Atakpamé, a city approximately 170 kilometres from Lomé, the capital of Togo. Passionate about her business, and wishing to promote it, Victorine hopes that with this loan she will be able to increase her volumes by finding new suppliers with lower prices, thereby increasing her profit margin.

Translated from French by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fish for resale

loans.name: Mabel

texts.en: Mabel O. sells building materials. She sells in Evbotubu Market in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She is 40 years old and married with 5 children. She needs the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more building materials to sell. She says thank you to all that make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more building materials to sell

loans.name: Catana

texts.en: Catana N. has 58 years old, active and in good health.He is a member of the Carabetovca village credit group. He lives in Carabetovca village, Basarabeasca district. Catana's main occupation is farming. He and his family have farmed  5,2 hectaires of arable land for cereal crops since 2000. Much of the work is done by mechanized equipment, but he must still do a lot of hard physical work. The business is registered as a farm operation, with the business location as Carabetovca village Basarabeasca district. The business was launched in 2000. This is Catana's second loan with Microinvest; the first, in the amount of 5000 lei was repaid on 11.05.07. The loan now requested is required to purchase farm chemicals and mechanical parts.

loans.use: purchase of farm chemicals and mechanical parts.

loans.name: Akossiwa

texts.fr: T. Akossiwa est une dame qui habite le quartier de yokoé, elle a pour activité génératrice de revenus la vente de charbons de bois, elle fait ce commerce depuis 2005 et ça marche bien pour elle, elle vend en gros et en détail ; elle est une cliente de wages qui a déjà obtenu un crédit de 150000F qu’elle a bien et convenablement remboursé, maintenant elle sollicite un autre crédit de 300000F pour pouvoir acheter des sacs de charbons de bois. Madame akossiwa est marié et mère de 03 enfants.
texts.en:
Akossiwa T. is a woman who lives in the Yokoé neighborhood. As a profit-earning enterprise, she sells charcoal. This has been her occupation since 2005, and it is going well for her. She sells both wholesale and retail. She is a client of WAGES and has previously received a loan of 150000F, which she paid back properly. Now, she is requesting a further loan of 300000F to buy sacks of charcoal. Mrs. T. is married with three children.

Translated from French by Jonah Durning-Hammond, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of charcoal

loans.name: Sherifattu

texts.en: Sherifattu B. sells wine and juice by wholesale and retail to her customers. She has been in this business for a long time. She loves this business because she makes lots of profit. She needs a loan to purchase more cartons of wine and juice to sell. She is 53 years old and married with four children. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more cartons of wine and juice to sell.

loans.name: Isidora

texts.es:
La señora Isidora S. G. pertenece al Banco Comunal “Nuestra Señora de la Paz”, vive en el Jr. Los Pinos Nº 538, Distrito de Tarapoto, departamento de San Martín. Es conviviente, tiene 52 años y es madre de 4 hijos, uno que todavía depende de ella. 

Con el primer préstamo de S/. 300.00, que fue por iniciativa propia, decidió vender relojes. Tiene 09 años trabajando con el Banco.

En la actualidad continua con el mismo negocio, que se encuentra ubicada en el Mercado Nº 02 de Tarapoto.
 Con el préstamo de S/2,200.00 que cancelará a plazo de 06 meses, desea invertirlo, implementando mas su negocio  comprando relojes  de todas las marcas y modelos, para damas, caballeros y niños, así como correas, pilas  para relojes y lentes de sol , etc.

Ambos, ella y su pareja, toman las decisiones en las ganancias de su negocio, nos cuenta, que se siente muy independiente y segura de si misma.

Isidora, manifiesta su agradecimiento a Manuela Ramos por permitirle crecer como empresaria y mujer.
texts.en:
Isidora S. G. is a member of the community bank "Nuestra Señora de la Paz”. She lives in the district of Tarapoto in the department of San Martín. She is partnered, 52 years of age and the mother of four children, one of whom is still a dependent. With her first loan of 300 soles, which she took on her own initiative, she decided to sell watches. She has been working with the bank for nine years. Today she is still in this same business, located in the Market Nº 02 of Tarapoto. With this loan for 2,200 soles, which she will repay over six months, she was to invest in her business by buying more watches of various brands and styles for women, men and children as well as watchbands, watch batteries and sunglasses and so on. She says that both she and her partners make decisions about the profits from the business, that she feels very independent and sure of herself. Isidora is grateful to Manuela Ramos for allowing her to grow both as an entrepreneur and as a woman.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy watches for women, men and children as well as watch batteries, and sunglasses

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en: Rosemary U., a 36-year-old married mother of three, sells medicine. She started her business in 2006 and hopes to expand it. Rosemary is requesting a loan of 80 000 NGN to purchase more medicines to sell. She sends thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Yaw

texts.en: For five years, Yaw A. has worked as a trader selling beverages and clothing in Siwdo.  He is married with four children and received an education through senior high school. His wife also works as a trader in the area.  Yaw is responsible for supporting his family by paying school fees, supplying clothing for his children and also paying the family’s bills. He will use this loan to increase the quantity of clothing he sells so as to increase his profit. He hopes to use the new profits from his business to reinvest back into his trade and expand his enterprise.

loans.use: To increase stock of clothing to sell

loans.name: Patricia

texts.es: Patricia es una joven muy alegre, tiene 23 años, vive en un cuarto alquilado y tiene muchas ganas de salir adelante, para ello, está dispuesta a trabajar mucho. Recorre las calles de la ciudad de Juliaca en busca de artefactos usados para comprar, posteriormente los arregla y vende, puesto que se dedica a la venta de artefactos de segunda mano, negocio muy rentable, ya que tiene muchos clientes que compran sus artefactos. Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es arreglar los artefactos, se distrae mucho haciéndolo, lleva 5 años realizando esta actividad y lo más difícil es recolectar los artefactos usados, ya que la gente no quiere venderlos a precios bajos, aun así Patricia sigue recorriendo las calles, con el firme propósito de tener una vida más digna. Este es su primer préstamo con MFP, y está muy decidida a pagar todas sus cuotas puntualmente para acceder a otro préstamo posteriormente, en su banco comunal es muy tranquila y siempre está atenta a los acuerdos a los que llegan las demás socias. Patricia invertirá los 1000 que solicita en la compra de más artefactos usados, para después de arreglarlos venderlos.
texts.en:
Patricia is a very happy young woman who is 23 years old. She lives in a rented room and has a great desire to get ahead for which she is prepared to work hard. She travels the streets of Juliaca in search of items to buy, which she then fixes and sells as her business is the sale of second-hand goods. The business is very profitable as she already has many clients who buy her items. What she most likes about her work is fixing the items as she entertains herself doing it. She has been doing this activity for 5 years and the most difficult thing is to collect the used items as people do not want to sell them at low prices. Even so, Patricia continues traveling through the streets with the firm purpose of having a more dignified life. This is her first loan with MFP, and she is very dedicated to making all of her payments punctually to be able to access another loan in the future. In her communal bank she is very calm and is always mindful of the agreements that the other members make. Patricia will invest the 1000 that she is requesting in the purchase of used items to then fix and sell them.

Translated from Spanish by Aimee Sostowski, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase Merchandise

loans.name: Nellie

texts.en: Mrs. Nellie D. is a bonafide resident of Tamban, Baliangao Misamis Occidental. She is 56 years old, married and blessed with 3 children who are married and have their own children. Their source of income is fishing and recently, she accessed a loan in the amount of PHP 5,000 for a motorized pumpboat. She's thankful to PMPC because through the Co-op they are able to purchase the motorized pumpboat.

loans.use: capital for motorized pumpboat

location.town: Calamba-Tamban Punta Miray Baliangao Misamis Occid

loans.name: Vieux

texts.fr: MR vieux N. est un agent de sécurité depuis quatre ans ,pour diversifier ses sources de revenu il fait du commerce de pantalons,de chaussures et de chemises ;c'est pour cela qu'il sollicite ce pret
texts.en:
Mr. Vieux N. has been a security guard for 4 years. To diversify his sources of income, he sells pants, shoes, and shirts. That is the reason why he is requesting this loan.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: selling clothing and shoes

loans.name: Leute

texts.en: Leute I., 22, is married with 1 child.  She has 3 years of experience in the plantation business.  She sells to the general public 5 days per week.  Leute has no previous loans with SPBD.  She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 200 Tala.  SPBD loans are Leute’s only access to capital because she is not able to qualify for a loan from traditional banks.

loans.use: Purchase chemicals, fertilizer, knifes, wheelbarrow and empty container for storing water,

loans.name: Nader

texts.en: Nader is a 23-year-old single man living with his parents. In 2008, he wanted to build his career so he decided to open a shop for furniture painting. Today, Nader is requesting to borrow $1,200 to purchase new painting tools to respond to the needs of the market.

loans.use: To purchase new painting tools

loans.name: Lino

texts.en:
Lino F.'s main source of income comes from making and selling baked goods in her community (0). She is a 39-year-old woman living in the town of Sesee K. She is married and has four school-age children. Lino has been engaged in this business for over two years and earns approximately 400 WST a month.

In 2008, Lino joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve  her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Lino has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1,000 WST from SPBD. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. 

Lino is now requesting a new loan of 1,500 WST which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be her second loan from SPBD. Lino plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About SPBD:
SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Laxmi

texts.en:
Mrs. Laxmi C. lives in Bhaishipati, Lalitpur. She lives in a single family household with four members: herself, her husband  and two sons.

Her husband, Mr. Bishnu C., is a driver. Her older son studies at the university and younger son is studying in grade 12.

Mrs. Laxmi C. started selling cows' milk three months ago. She already owns a cow. Now she is requesting a loan of Rs 10,000.00 to buy another young cow to sell milk, because she lives in a growing neighborhood and in that area the demand for milk is increasing. In Nepal, people love to drink cows' milk so the demand for milk is increasing constantly.

loans.use: to buy one more cow

loans.name: Elsa

texts.es:
La señora Elsa pertenece al Banco Comunal “Señor D. la Caña”  que esta ubicado D. el distrito D. Plateria, Provincia D. Puno, Departamento D. Puno, ella tiene 53 años D. edad, estado civil casada y es madre D. 04 hijos y tiene estudios D. primaria completa, vive en el centro poblado D. Ccota.

La señora trabaja con el movimiento Manuela Ramos hace 01 año,  con un préstamo inicial D. S/. 500.00 nuevos soles  para la compra D. lanas para elaboración D. artesanías. 

En este momento ella solicito un préstamo D. S/. 800.00 Nuevos soles, para la compra D. lana acrílica D. diferentes colores, para la elaboración D. artesanías en miniatura las cuales las venD. en las ferias D. Plateria.

Su mayor sueño es poner una tienda D. abarrotes en su centro poblado.

A ella le gustan las reuniones.
texts.en:
Elsa belongs to the Señor D. la Caña Comunal Bank, which is located in the Plateria district, Puno province, Puno department. She is 53, married, and has four children. She has an elementary school education. She lives in the Ccota town center. She has worked with the Manuela Ramos Movement for one year. With her initial loan for 500 PEN she bought wool to make her handicrafts. She is now asking for a loan for 800 PEN to buy different colors of acrylic wool to make her handicraft miniatures. She will sell them in the fairs in Plateria. Her biggest dream is to have a grocery store in her town center. She likes the meetings.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy different colors of acrylic wool

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida Y., 44, lives with her husband Robert, 39, a market vendor, amongst the poor communities of Pasay City. They have seven children, all but one of whom are in school. Aida has been a member of the Center for Community Transformation Credit Cooperative (CCT) since 2006.

Aida owns and manages a stall inside a market complex selling different types of footwear, such as sandals and flip-flops. She started this business six years ago. Her market stall is very near a commuter train station, making it accessible to buyers. Her sandals are in demand so she employs an assistant to help her attend to customers. She makes 34,000 PHP a month, enough to sustain her family’s needs, including education expenses for her children. She has been able to purchase a motorized tricycle, which now provides an additional source of income for the family.

Competition amongst individual entrepreneurs in the market complex is prevalent and inevitable; this however, is healthy competition. Aida needs a loan of 50,000 PHP to be able to purchase more stock of sandals and flip-flops to give customers more options from which to choose. Aida spends time and money visiting manufacturers of sandals and other footwear to obtain a better selection. That’s why she dreams of having her own vehicle to transport her goods. She also wishes to have her own house and lot soon.

About CCT
The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase more stock of sandals and flip-flops

loans.name: Leonard Nyamongo

texts.en:
Leonard is married to Jackline and they have no children yet.

Leonard operates three businesses: a clinic, beauty shop and rental houses. He has been in the business for two years. He joined KADET through a marketing promotion and has no previous credit history. Leonard intends to use his loan to buy a motorbike for a taxi business so as to further diversiy his businesses.

The Clients' area of business is in a slum, it has a vast population. With the extra profit, the client shall buy more motorbikes. Hopes and dreams of the client are to own motor vehicles for taxi and car hire as the client believes he is focused and hardworking.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: Client intends to buy a motorbike for a taxi business so as to diversify his businesses.

loans.name: Diane

texts.fr: V. Diane est née en 1977 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Diane est mariée à HOUNGAVOU Pierre, un chauffeur, et est mère de cinq enfants tous scolarisés, dont quatre sont à sa charge. Diane vit avec son conjoint et ses enfants à Gbokpa à Djèrègbé, village situé à l’entrée de Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Diane vient en aide à Pierre dans les charges de la famille. Diane n’a jamais fréquenté l’école. Il y a de cela trois ans déjà que Diane vend du charbon de bois et de l’huile de palme à son domicile. Diane s’approvisionne au marché Ouando à Porto-Novo. Diane a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits à ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés. En vue d’accroître la taille de son activité et de faire face à la demande de sa clientèle, Diane sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
V. Diane was born in 1977 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She is married to HOUNGAVOU Pierre, a chauffeur, and is the mother of five children who are all in school. Four of the children are in her care. Diane lives with her spouse and her children in Gbokpa in Djèrègbé, a village located at the entrance of Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. Diane aids her husband with regard to family expenses. She has never attended school. For three years already, she has been selling charcoal and palm oil at her home. She stocks up at the Ouando market in Porto-Novo. She has benefited before from two ALIDé loans, which she has repaid. With the aim of expanding her business and coping with customer demands, she’s requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of charcoal and containers of palm oil

loans.name: Phum

texts.en: Phum M. is 44 years old and generates a daily income of $5 per day by selling fish. She is married to Yan, who is 32 years old and owns a trailer-motorbike taxi service. He also earns approximately $5 each day to help manage the family's expenses. They have four children who go to the local public school. This fish season, Phum M. and her husband hope to earn more money by investing as fish catchers but they don't have enough capital. Because of this, Phum M. would like to seek a loan to buy nets, traps, and a fishing boat for fishing activities. Phum M.'s husband appears in the photo.

loans.use: To buy nets, traps, and a boat

loans.name: Matilde

texts.en:
Matilde P. is from the village of Lakas, Mambajao Camiguin Province. She is 46 years old and is married with 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Matilde owns and operates a business venture in the services sector operating a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing tricycle transport services to local community members. Matilde has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Matilde joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Matilde has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Matilde is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Matilde from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Paul Maina

texts.en: Paul is 23 years old and single.  For the past year and a half, Paul has been selling home products such as flour, rice, tea leaves, and stationery.  He has one employee at his store. The main business challenge that he faces are fluctuating prices of commodities. He plans to use his loan of $275 to buy ten dozen kilograms flour, five cartoons of cooking oil, and other home products. He aspires to be a wholesaler in future.  Paul describes himself as hardworking, honest and patient.

loans.use: To buy flour, cooking oil, and other home products

loans.name: Jessica

texts.es: Desde hace 20 años  se dedica a la venta y elaboración de zapatillas para niños, el trabajo se divide de la siguiente manera, Jessica se encarga de hacer los contactos para las ventas, la compra de material, por lo cual  es muy difícil encontrarla en su taller, al contrario su esposo, se encarga de la elaboración y permanece  durante todo el día en el local. Ambos se dedican mucho al  trabajo porque quieren brindar un futuro mejor a sus hijos, aunque muchas veces sienten cansancio, el hecho de trabajar y salir adelante los motiva y les da las  ganas para seguir. Poco a poco están mejorando su taller y buscan  encontrar un  local más grande y contratar a mayor cantidad de trabajadores para así aumentar la producción.Es el décimo préstamo que tiene con MFP y  siempre se ha caracterizado por ser muy puntual en sus pagos.Con el dinero del crédito quiere comprar más cantidad de moldes de zapatillas con lo que logrará abastecer los pedidos de su clientela.
texts.en:
For twenty years she has been devoted to selling and making shoes for children. The work is divided in the following manner. Jessica is in charge of making the contacts for the sales and buying the material. Therefore, it is very difficult to find her in her shop. On the other hand, her husband is in charge of making the shoes. He stays in the shop during the whole day. Both of them work very hard because they want to give their children a better future. Even though they are often tired, working and getting ahead motivates them and gives them the desire to keep going. Little by little they are improving their shop. They are looking for a larger place and to hire more workers in order to increase production. It is the tenth loan that she has had with MFP. She has always been characterized as being very punctual with her payments. She wants to use the money from the loan to buy more shoe molds in order to fill the customers’ orders.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy merchandise to stock her business

loans.name: Mrs. Kao Mom Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. K. Mom is the village bank president of a group of five who all live in Pech Changva village in Takeo province. She is a cart maker. Since her cart-making business is doing well, she wants to expand it, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more supplies to make more carts to sell. 

Mrs. K. Mom is a widow with two children, one of whom is a fruit seller while the younger one is attending the local school.

loans.use: to buy more cart-making supplies

loans.name: Aziza

texts.en:
Their education is the most important inheritance Aziza and her husband can give to their two dear children. They are both very responsible parents, and they work very hard in agriculture and farming so that they can give their children the opportunity to finish school – an opportunity they never had due to poor finances. This happy mother has been working in agriculture since getting married and, with the unconditional help of her husband, she buys and sells cattle in order to cover the family’s most urgent needs. Even so, she now finds herself with more expenditures, and she would like a loan in order to increase their capital by increasing their production. Aziza and her family are waiting for your quick response.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New Western culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History:

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase cattle to expand the business.

loans.name: Alaa

texts.en: Alaa is a 21-year-old man who lives in Tyre, southern Lebanon. Alaa has been working as a car repairer since 2004. He also sells used car spare parts. He decided on doing his business because of his experience and because he likes to this job. He likes challenges and for him, repairing a car is always challenging. When he first started his business, he had some difficulties building networks and purchasing all the necessary tools for his work. Now, for the time, he has requested a loan from Al Majmoua because he wants to purchase new and more sophisticated tools, and to renew some stone rock decorations at his house because he plans to get married. In the future, he hopes and plans to keep improving his work and his financial situation.

loans.use: To purchase new and more sophisticated tools.

loans.name: Guillerma

texts.en:
Guillerma O. is from the village of  San Juan Gingoog City. She is 45 years old. Guillerma is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Guillerma owns and operates a business providing motorela services used to transport passengers to local communites. Guillerma is just starting this business, but still has a vulcanizing shop business.

In 2009, Guillerma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Guillerma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase materials needed to provide service. Guillerma is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Guillerma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Josefina

texts.en: Josefina F.'s main source of income comes primarily from selling Nipa palm products to local community members. She is 47 years old, married and has three school-age children. They are from the village of Garang, Tangub City. Josefina has been in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2009, Josefina joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Josefina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Josefina is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw materials needed to make products for sale. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials needed to make products for sale

loans.name: 11Th Street United Business Group

texts.en: For more than 10 years, Amara S. has been selling car tires retail in Monrovia, Liberia. He is 46 years old, married and has three children ranging in age from 10 to 17. He attended Arabic School through 12th grade but could not continue due to financial problems. Amara sells his tires at affordable prices and talks to customers in a nice manner which keeps customers returning. But he's had trouble finding adequate cash in order to buy more inventory. He plans to use his portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to purchase more tires to increase his stock. His goal is to send his children to school and build a house. Amara is the leader of this group of five borrowers called "11th Street United Business". In the photo that accompanies this profile, Amara is the one holding the sign. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, this non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more tires for resale

loans.name: Nuevo Progreso Group

texts.en:
Felicia is 56 years old and she is the coordinator of her group 'Nuevo Progreso' (New Progress). Her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients generally, many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti. Her group is located in the slums north of the capital, Santo Domingo, a crime-ridden area where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her husband.

Felicia is excited to be taking her fourth loan with Esperanza  after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business running a small food stand selling rice, salads, beans, and staples such as yuca and plantains. She will use the profits to save towards improving her home as well as helping her community. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: rice, salads, beans, and staples such as yuca and plantains to sell to her clients

loans.name: Chhoeun's Group

texts.en: Mr. Chhoeun N. is 51 years old and the village bank president who has selected by the 19 members, who are located in Krang Sbaek village in Takeo province. Each member of this group loan will use their loan for different purposes. Mr. Chhoeun N. is a farmer who owns a one-hectare field to cultivate rice. His wife, Mrs. Yorn Oung, is a tamarind seller who earns a small income to support her family. Mr. Chhoeun N. is requesting a loan to purchase a motorcycle to provide transport for his child, who is a seamstress in a garment factory.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for his child

loans.name: Juvy

texts.en:
Juvy G. is from the village of Research Minante 1 in Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 46 years old and married. To make a living, Juvy owns and operates a general store where she sells food and daily-use products in the local community. Juvy is just starting this business.

In 2006, Juvy joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Juvy is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. This will be Juvy's seventh loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 
About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Amarbayasgalan

texts.en:
Amarbayasgalan is 50 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Arhangai province in western Mongolia. Her family enjoys a comfortable lifestyle and have been living for twenty-five years at their current address. The family supports and helps Amarbayasgalan’s business.

Amarbayasgalan has operated her vegetable-trading business since 1995, both wholesale and retail. Now she has a stall in Hasuu market and aims to expand her business in the future. With her income, she has bought a car and electric appliances, but most important is that they have got a house. Now the family is building a house for her oldest son using her business revenues.

Amarbayasgalan is a hardworking, modest woman. She is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more vegetables and seed potatoes at a wholesale price.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetables and seed potatoes to sell

loans.name: Mohammad

texts.en:
Mohammad S. is a young man from Bethlehem region. He lives with his parents and shares household expenses with his father. Mohammad is a cook at the community center in Bethlehem. Mohammed's father is a taxi driver in the city. Since both have limited incomes, it wasn't easy to buy furniture without taking a $3000 loan from FATEN.

Mohammad tries to save as much as possible from his decent income, but the difficult situation in Bethlehem made it harder for Mohammed to help his father without taking the loan.

In the picture, Mohammed sits in the FATEN office while receiving his loan.

loans.use: Purchase home furniture

loans.name: Las Exitosas Group

texts.es:
L. Señorita Katherine tiene 19 años, es L. presidenta del nuevo grupo “LAS EXITOSAS”, ellas son 10 socias, todas viven en el distrito D. Los Olivos, departamento D. Lima. 
ElL. cuenta con un pequeño negocio D. productos D. belleza venD. todo tipo D. productos como labiales, esmaltes  para uñas, perfumes, cremas etc.
 También se ayuda haciendo chocolatería, L. socia empezó a vender chocolates para sus amigas entre ellas se pasaban L. voz y le  recomendaban a nuevos clientes es así que poco a poco amplio su negocio. L. mayora D. sus clientes son jóvenes. Sus ingresos le permiten cubrir sus gastos D. estudio y transporte  porque elL. estudia turismo y hotelería en un instituto. Quisiera invertir el préstamo en L. compra D. mercadería particularmente D. ropa para señoras ya que incursionara en ese negocio, para más adelante le gustaría tener una tienda granD. porque todavía venD. en su casa y a domicilio, le gustaría mostrar sus productos para tener mas ganancias.

* Katherine es L.  cuarta D. las paradas esta vestida con pantalón Jean y chompa negra
texts.en:
Señorita Katherine is 19 years old, and is the president of the new "Las Exitosas" (The Successful) group. There are 10 women who are members and they all live in the Los Olivos district in the department of Lima. She has a small business selling beauty products such as lipstick, nail varnish, perfume, creams etc. She also makes chocolates, originally for her friends, but word got around and her friends recommended her to new customers so that, little by little, her business grew. Most of her customers are young people. Her income allows her to cover her study and transport expenses, as she is studying tourism and hotel management in an institute. She would like to invest this loan in the purchase of merchandise, particularly women's clothing, as she is already getting into this business and she would like to have a large shop some time in the future. She currently sells clothing from her house and door-to-door, but she would like to have somewhere to display her goods in order to increase her earnings. * Katherine is the fourth woman standing on the left, wearing jeans and a black sweater.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy women's clothing for resale

loans.name: Nila

texts.es: Nila, de 48 años, es una mujer muy sincera y trabajadora, vive en su casa propia y lo que más desea es mejorar su calidad de vida. Los productos que con tanto esfuerzo y dedicación han logrado cultivar, le han ayudado mucho en el progreso de su trabajo. Todas las mañanas trabaja en sus tierras, ya que sabe que del cuidado que le brinde a sus platanales y cafetales dependerá la calidad de los productos que obtenga. Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es cuidar sus cultivos y se siente muy feliz cuado los ve crecer abundantemente, tiene 28 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es llevar lo cosechado hasta el mercado de la ciudad de la Merced, que es el lugar donde lo vende, ya que los sacos en donde lleva los productos son muy pesados. En adelante, espera mejorar sus productos, para así poder obtener mejores precios. Este es el segundo crédito con MFP, sabe que tiene que pagar todas sus cuotas puntualmente y esta dispuesta a hacerlo. En su grupo comunal es una socia muy solidaria y responsable. Con los mil nuevos soles que solicita, comprará más abono para mejorar la producción de sus plantaciones.
texts.en:
Nila, age 48, is a very sincere and hard-working woman. She lives in her own house, and what she desires most is to improve her quality of life. With great effort and dedication, she has been able to cultivate crops which have helped her greatly in the progress of her work. Every morning, she works in her fields, since she knows that the quality of the products she obtains depends on the care she provides to her banana and coffee plantings. What she likes best about her work is taking care of her crops, and she feels very happy when she sees them growing abundantly. She has done this work for 28 years, and she thinks the hardest part is taking her crops to the market in the city of Merced, which is where she sells them, since the sacks in which she transports her products are very heavy. In the future, she hopes to improve her products so that she can obtain better prices. This is her second loan with MFP; she knows that she has to make all of her payments on time, and she is determined to do so. In her communal bank, she is a very responsible member with a strong sense of solidarity. With the 1000 Peruvian new soles she is requesting, she will buy more fertilizer to improve the productivity of her crops.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying more fertilizer

loans.name: Sokchamroeun

texts.en:
Miss SokChamroeun P. is single and lives with her widowed mother and brother on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. Her mother runs a grocery store from their home.  

SokChamroeun is a silk weaver. She does not have enough capital to purchase silk material for her weaving business. So she is asking for her second loan of $300 to make the purchases. 

Photo: Sokchamroeun is standing in front of her mother’s grocery store.

loans.use: To buy silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.name: Alnie

texts.en:
Alnie F. is from the town of Sto. Niño. She is 47 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. Alnie owns and operates a farming business, planting and harvesting rice for sale. Alnie has been engaged in her business for over 25 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month from it.

Alnie joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alnie has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Alnie from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business and supplement the family's income. Alnie wishes for CEVI to continue to expand so more farmers could avail of its programs.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Escolastico

texts.es: Escolastico vive en la zona  Pomposillo, Provincia  Aroma, del Departamento La Paz, junto a su   esposa y sus hijos  los cuales son personas mayores y tiene sus familias propias. Escolastico se dedica a la cría de ganado vacuno cuya producción de leche la vende a Pil Andina (Planta industrializadota de leche). El crédito será para la compra de ganado.  Es el primer  crédito en Impro y el primero vía Kiva.
texts.en:
Escolastico lives in the zone of Pomposillo, province of Aroma, in the department of La Paz. He lives with his wife and children who are grown and have their own families. Escolastico works raising cattle that produce milk that he sells to Pil Andina (an industrial milk plant). This loan will be for buying cattle. It is his first loan from Impro and his first time on Kiva.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Fanning, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cattle

loans.name: Ligaya Suarez's Group

texts.en:
Ligaya S. is from the village of San Jose, Enrile, Cagayan. She is the leader of a six-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.
Ligaya is 40 years old, married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Ligaya operates a family member's business venture in the food sector preparing and selling pork and chicken barbecue. Ligaya has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 3,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2010, Ligaya joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be her 1st from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies. 

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Jose Wilmer

texts.es:
José Wilmer es un padre de familia de 31 años de edad que reside junto a su esposa y a su hijo en el distrito pesquero de San José, una zona que pertenece a la provincia de Lambayeque y que se encuentra ubicado a más de veinte minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica desde hace mas de seis años al procesamiento y comercialización de pescado seco – salado. El adquiere pescado fresco en el terminal pesquero de la región para luego procesarlo y venderlo en los diversos mercados de la zona. Su esposa lo apoya en esta actividad y juntos tratan de salir adelante y progresar apoyándose en su negocio.

José Wilmer desea adquirir más pescado fresco para así poder ampliar sus ventas y percibir mas ingresos. Por ello ha decidido solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1500 nuevos soles con los cuales piensa lograr su objetivo.

José es una persona tranquila y responsable. Anteriormente ya ha tenido créditos con Edpyme Alternativa y ha demostrado puntualidad y responsabilidad al momento de asumir sus pagos.
texts.en:
José Wilmer is a 31 year old father who lives with his wife and son in the fishing district of San José, an area that is part of the Lambayeque province, located more than 20 minutes from the city of Chiclayo.  

For over 6 years he has worked processing and selling dried salted fish.  He purchases fresh fish at the fishing port and then processes and sells it in many area markets.  His wife helps him and together they try to make progress and support each other in their business. 

José Wilmer would like to purchase more fresh fish in order to increase his sales and earn more income.  For this reason he has requested a loan of 1500 new sols from Edpyme Alternativa which he plans to use to achieve his goal.  

José is a relaxed and responsible person.  He has had prior loans with Edpyme Alternativa and has proven himself to be punctual and responsible with his payments.

loans.use: To acquire more fresh fish to increase his sales.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 35-year-old single woman living with her parents. She has owned a cattle farm in her town since 2006. And she has been working in this field for the past 13 years on a local farm. She produces dairy products such as milk. She helps her father who works as a farmer in the household. Today, she is requesting a loan of $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase fodder for her cattle to get a good quality of milk, especially before the winter season. This is because it is very popular in Lebanon to buy milk from cattle farms and make special Lebanese dairy products.

loans.use: To purchase fodder

loans.name: Elena

texts.es:
Elena A. Rodríguez de 54 años, procedente del departamento de Bolívar desde el año de 1999 en condiciones de desplazamiento, llegó a Barranquilla con su esposo y sus 9 hijos en las edades de 14 a 27 y  se le ocurrió la idea de elaborar bollos (Envueltos a base de maíz y queso) aprovechando el conocimiento de la técnica y su experiencia en el oficio; fue así como inició con 13 mazorcas y elaboró 12 bollos que vendió, y que desde ese momento, se han convertido en el sustento principal de su hogar, pues en la actualidad ha aumentado su producción a 100 bollos diarios. Si usted  visita a Elena puede encontrarla en pleno proceso, con sus compañeros de producción, que son sus hijos,: entre todos deshojan el maíz , desprenden los granos, que someten a molienda, para luego amasarlos, envolverlos en las mismas hojas del bollo, amarrarlos y finalmente someterlos a la respectiva cocción; para que cuando ya están listos, puedan ser adquiridos mediante su compra por los clientes, ubicados en el mismo barrio donde vive y especialmente  en tiendas del sector, allí son vendidos al consumidor final. Para el desarrollo de esta actividad, Elena cuenta con un molino eléctrico, al que ya es hora de hacerle una buena reparación y también tiene   todos las herramientas necesaria para el proceso; Este es su segundo financiamiento con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, con él comprará enseres menores, reparará su molino,  y comprará laminas de eternit, cemento y baldosas  para adecuar su pisos y proteger su espacio productivo, debido a que cuando llueve se filtra el agua, generando condiciones de deterioro e inseguridad al trabajar.
Elena cuenta, que antes de estar vinculada a la Fundación, mantenía créditos costosos para poder comprar su materia prima e insumos, ahora se siente mas tranquila porque está mas holgada con el capital adicional que le presta esta organización; igualmente manifiesta que su negocio ha crecido tanto en ventas como en estructura con este impulso. Su sueño se concentra  mas adelante en finalizar su vivienda, para mejorar sus condiciones habitacionales, que tanto convienen también al negocio, en su imagen y presentación y este es justamente su gran desafío.
texts.en:
Elena A. Rodríguez is 54 years old.  She has lived in Bolívar department since 1999.  She arrived in Barranquilla with her husband and her 9 children aged between 14 and 27.  She had the idea to start making 'bollos' (corn and cheese-based wraps), making use of her knowledge and experience in the business.  She started with 13 corncobs and made 12 'bollos' which she then sold.  From that moment, her business has become the main source of support for her household.  She has increased her production to 100 'bollos' a day.  If you visited Elena you would find her in the middle of making her 'bollos' with her children who are her production colleagues.  Between them they shuck the corn, remove the grain which they then mill, make the dough, wrap the 'bollos' up in the corn husks, tie them up and finally cook them.  When they are ready they are bought by her customers who are in her neighborhood, especially those who own stores where the 'bollos' are finally sold to the end customer.

To carry out her activity, Elena has an electric mill which now needs to be repaired and all the other equipment which she needs for her production process.  This is the second loan which Elena has had from Fundación Mario Santo Domingo.  She will use it to buy small utensils, to repair her mill and to buy corrugated metal sheeting, cement and tiles to adapt her premises and protect her production space because when it rains the water drips in which causes damage and lack of safety while she is working.

Elena tells us that before she was a member of Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, she used expensive loans to buy raw material and ingredients.  Now she feels more relaxed because she is more comfortable with the capital which this organization provides her with.  She also says that her business has grown both in terms of sales and in structure as a result of this investment.  Her dream for the future is to finish the building work on her home, to improve her living conditions which are so important for her business too both in terms of image and presentation.  This is her biggest challenge.

loans.use: To buy small utensils, repair her mill and buy sheets of corrugated metal, cement and tiles to adapt her property and protect her production space

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Annet N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Bugembe, in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is single and has 1 child. One of her children is currently in school. Annet has a business of a library, which she has had for 1 year. She also has a business of car parking.  

To help expand her business, Annet has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to purchase video CDs and DVDs. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Annet hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees. In the future, Annet hopes to study hair dressing. Annet is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by protecting herself.

loans.use: video CDs and DVDs

loans.name: Cresina

texts.en:
From the town of Trinidad, 60-year-old Cresina M. is married and has children. The owner and manager of a sari-sari (general) store for almost 15 years already, Cresina sells various products including shampoo, bread and soft drinks, and hopes to acquire new items, including rice, to expand her product offering.

Cresina joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan from CEVI, she is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her store.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Marina Estela

texts.es: Marina Estela C. de 64 años de edad, reside en el departamento de Ahuachapán, en donde vive junto a dos hijos mayores de edad quienes se dedican a trabajar. Marina es una mujer muy emprendedora, la cual trabaja muy duro comercializando películas a las afueras de su hogar, así mismo comercializa ropa, cortinas y sabanas, lo que le permite contar con otras fuentes de ingreso para su sostén. Ambos negocios son de mucha importancia para ella, por lo que solicita un préstamo por medio del cual pueda invertir en sus ventas, comprando mayor cantidad de artículos para el hogar, así mismo para invertir en más películas, por medio de esto Marina espera mejorar su economía.
texts.en:
Marina Estela C., 64, lives in Ahuachapán department with her two adult children who work.   Marina is a very enterprising woman.  She works hard selling movies outside her house.  She also sells clothing, curtains and sheets which allows her to have an additional source of income for her support.  

Both businesses are very important for her so she is asking for a loan to invest in her sales buying larger amounts of items for the home as well as more movies.  Marina hopes to improve her economy this way.

loans.use: To buy curtains, sheets and movies to sell.

loans.name: Djiguiya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Djiguiya est constitué de 6 femmes  toutes mariées, ayant en moyenne 43 ans, 6 enfants et vivant dans des grandes familles traditionnelles à TENE dans la préfecture de SAN (Région de Ségou, République du Mali).Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de voisinage.
Elles mènent différentes activités  telles la vente de poisson fumés et fris.  Et cela depuis plusieurs années  Les femmes du groupe Djiguiya  sont  très sollicitées dans leurs activités. 
Dans le souci de satisfaire le besoin  de leur clientèle, le groupe Djiguiya à décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y a 4 ans. Elles sont à leur neuvième prêt de groupe. 
MAMA K. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 5 gros cartons de poissons fumés et 9 paniers de poisson fris à SAN, tous les Lundis à SAN puisse que les femmes des pêcheurs viennent vendre en gros à la foire de SAN.  Elle revend à TENE et dans les différentes foires hebdomadaires. Elle espère sur un bénéfice mensuel  de 26000 FCFA somme qui lui  permettra de rembourser le prêt et de réinvestir dans son activité.
texts.en:
The group named Djiguiya is made up of 6 women members who are all married and averaging 43 years of age. They each have 6 children and they live in large traditional families in Tene, a quarter in the city of San (Region of Segou in the Republic of Mali). These women know each other through family and as neighbors. 

They each carry out different businesses, such as the sale of smoked and fried fish. For many years the businesses of these women have been well solicited. With the goal of meeting client demand, the Djiguiya group decided four years ago to come together and request a loan from Soro Yiriwaso. They are on their ninth group loan. 

Mama K. will use her loan to purchase 5 large cartons of smoked fish and 9 baskets of fried fish in San. Every Monday in San the wives of the fishermen come to sell the fish in wholesale at San. She resells the products in Tene and in various fairs held weekly. She expects to earn a monthly income of 26000 FCFA and it will allow her to repay the loan and to reinvest in her business.

loans.use: To purchase smoked and fried fish.

loans.name: Yolanda Maribel

texts.es:
Yolanda tiene 27 años de edad, es conviviente, y tiene tres hijos, vive junto a su familia en el distrito de Tambogrande, un distrito de la provincia de Piura, en la región del mismo nombre, caracterizado por que sus pobladores se dedican principalmente al cultivo de frutas.

Yolanda se dedica a la venta de productos de belleza por catálogo, ella cuenta con un grupo de clientes que le compran sus productos con frecuencia, mientras más pedidos le realizan obtiene mas puntos de parte de la empresa que le provee los productos y por consiguiente obtiene mayores ganancias. Por este motivo siempre se esfuerza por obtener cada vez más clientes.

Adicionalmente trabaja vendiendo aves de corral, con los ingresos que percibe de estas actividades apoya a su familia, con el sostenimiento de la economía de su familia. Ella trabaja incansablemente por mantenerse en estas actividades.

Yolanda desea implementar su stock de productos de belleza para poder satisfacer la demanda con la que actualmente cuenta, por ello ha solicitado a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 500 nuevos soles.
texts.en:
Yolanda is 27 years old.  She lives with her partner and three children in Tambogrande district, in Piura province, in the region of the same name.  This area is noted for the fact that its inhabitants are mainly fruit growers.

Yolanda's business is selling beauty products through a catalog.  She has a group of customers who buy her products frequently.  The more orders her customers make, the more points she earns from the company that provides the products and, hence, the more profits she makes.  For this reason, she is always working hard to attract more customers.  Yolanda also works selling poultry.  She uses the income she makes from these business activities to support her family financially.

Yolanda works untiringly to keep going in her businesses.  She would like to add to her stock of beauty products so that she can meet the demand she currently has.  For this reason, she is requesting a loan for 500 Peruvian soles from Edpyme Alternativa.

loans.use: To increase her stock of beauty products

loans.name: Mercedes

texts.es:
La señora Mercedes es socia del banco comunal Mujeres Del 2000, del Distrito de Calleria, departamento de Ucayali, tiene 60 años de edad, está casada y su esposo se desempeña como motocarrista (transportista), tiene 2 hijos ya mayores de edad.
La señora Mercedes lleva trabajando con los préstamos de Manuela Ramos desde hace 12 años, tiempo que ha estado cumpliendo mes a mes todo sus pagos.  Ella se dedica a la venta de productos de belleza, esta actividad la realiza en su casa ya que tiene sus productos en exhibición.

Su nuevo préstamo de  S/. 1,000.00 nuevos soles lo invertirá en la compra de  3 perfumes para varón, 2 perfumes para damas, 2 cremas para mano, 1 loción para el cuerpo,2 colonias para bebes, 2 talcos para bebes, una vitrina para conservar y mostrar mejor sus productos el cual lo hace muy orgullosa.
La señora Mercedes quiere seguir trabajando con Manuela Ramos mucho tiempo más porque se siente bien estando en ese grupo de personas afortunadas por tener un capital para trabajar y así poder ayudar a su esposo.
texts.en:
Mrs. Merceses is a member of the "Mujeres del 2000" communal bank, district of Calleria in the department of Ucayali.  She is 60 years old and married and her husband works as a transport driver.  She has two adult children.

Mrs. Mercedes has been working with loans from Manuela Ramos for 12 years.  She has always made her payments on time.  She sells beauty products out of her home.
